snippet: My dear Sir — ^I meant to have written much sooner, andtold how greatly I was impressed by my visit to Barnsmuir.

snippet: It is no ordinary recoUection that I have of Barnsmuir, andshould rejoice if, through grace and wisdom from above, itcould be made to subserve that highest of aU good which hasfruit in eternity.

title: A selection from the correspondence of the late Thomas Chalmers /
author: Chalmers, Thomas
snippet: The picture you sent is superior to that at Barnsmuir, andin some respects more impressive ; but there are in it a force,and vivacity, and decision, which, though at the distance ofa thousand miles from aught that borders on the masculine,yet are not so true to the original as the other, which presents, I think, a more faithful exhibition of that sensitivelyand exquisitely feminine expression which formed the peculiarcharm and grace of her character.

title: A selection from the correspondence of the late Thomas Chalmers /
author: Chalmers, Thomas
snippet: (Captain Rankine, of Barnsmuir, had three daughters : the eldest,Christian, married to Mr. Fortune ; the second, Anne, married to theRev. Mr. Brown, of Kilrenny ; the third, Susan, married to the Rev.Mr. Watson, minister of Leuchars, a parish not far from Kilmany.

title: A selection from the correspondence of the late Thomas Chalmers /
author: Chalmers, Thomas
snippet: On the Sunday morning we walked in a family groupfrom Barnsmuir to Kilrenny — a beautiful day, and most interesting road, all the turns and objeots of which you wellknow.

title: A selection from the correspondence of the late Thomas Chalmers /
author: Chalmers, Thomas
snippet: The two eldestdaughters are farther advanced than were Kirsty and SusanRankine when I first knew them, and, indeed, have a verystrong resemblance, both in mind and appearance, to theBarnsmuir ladies of that generation.

title: A selection from the correspondence of the late Thomas Chalmers /
author: Chalmers, Thomas
snippet: I got down to dinner, and met acompany of coast-siders — Mr. Brown, of Kilrenny, Mr. andMrs. Wilson, of Anster, Hall Pringle and his sister, from Largo, &c. I stopped at Barnsmuir all night.

title: A selection from the correspondence of the late Thomas Chalmers /
author: Chalmers, Thomas
snippet: Mr. Fortune, now at Barnsmuir, sent his gig for me on thelast Saturday of the year.

title: A selection from the correspondence of the late Thomas Chalmers /
author: Chalmers, Thomas
snippet: I went down to Anster onthe Saturday— ^walked to Kilrenny after breakfast — preachedthere in the afternoon — dined with Mr. Brown, and walkedin the evening to Barnsmuir with Mr. Fortune.

title: A selection from the correspondence of the late Thomas Chalmers /
author: Chalmers, Thomas
snippet: I left Mr. Bell in his gigearly on Monday morning, called at Barnsmuir, where MissFortune, now of sixteen, bears a striking resemblance to hermother.
